sen.j: 大黒天（だいこくてん）とは、ヒンドゥー教のシヴァ神の化身であるマハーカーラ（サンスクリット語：、音写：摩訶迦羅など）のことである。
sen.e: Daikokuten means Maha kala (Sanskrit :, transliteration : 摩訶迦羅) that is a reincarnation of Shiva, a deity of the Hindu religion.
Daikokuten means Maha kala (Sanskrit :, transliteration : 摩訶迦羅) that is a reincarnation of Shiva, a deity of the Hindu religion.
Daikokuten means Maha kala (Sanskrit:, transliteration: 摩訶迦羅) that is a reincarnation of Shiva, a deity of the Hindu religion.

sen.j: 密教の大黒天
sen.e: Daikokuten of Mikkyo (Esoteric Buddhism)
Daikokuten of Mikkyo (Esoteric Buddhism)
Daikokuten of Mikkyo (Esoteric Buddhism)

sen.j: - マハーカーラが元になり出来た密教の神である。
sen.e: It is a deity of Mikkyo evolved from Maha kala.
It is a deity of Mikkyo evolved from Maha kala.
It is a deity of Mikkyo evolved from Maha kala.

sen.j: 仏教の大黒天
sen.e: Daikokuten of Buddism
Daikokuten of Buddism
Daikokuten of Buddhism

sen.j: 密教の大黒天が元になり出来た仏教の天部に属する神である。
sen.e: It is a deity of Buddhism evolved from Daikokuten of Mikkyo that belongs to Tenbu (deities who reside in a heavenly realms in which the souls of living beings transmigrate from one to another).
It is a deity of Buddhism evolved from Daikokuten of Mikkyo that belongs to Tenbu (deities who reside in the heavenly realms where the souls of living beings transmigrate from one to another).
In Buddhism, Daikokuten is a deity that has its origins in the Daikokuten of Mikkyo and is one of the Tenbu (deities who reside in the heavenly realms).
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました

sen.j: （本来の仏教では神及び多神を否定している。）
sen.e: (Original Buddhism denies the existence of deities and polytheism)
(Original Buddhism denies the existence of deities and polytheism)
(Original Buddhism denies the existence of deities and polytheism.)

sen.j: （現在でも神や多神を認めない仏教宗派もある）
sen.e: (Even at present, some sects of Buddhism denies the existence of deities and polytheism)
(Even at present, some sects of Buddhism deny the existence of deities and polytheism)
(Even at present, some sects of Buddhism deny the existence of deities and polytheism.)

sen.j: 神道の大黒天
sen.e: Daikokuten of Shinto religion
Daikokuten of the Shinto religion
Daikokuten of the Shinto religion

sen.j: 密教の大黒天が元になり、大国主命と神仏習合して出来た神道の神で、七福神の一柱としても知られる。
sen.e: It is a deity of Shinto religion that was created by combining Daikouten of Mikkyo and Okuninushi-no mikoto, so called syncretism of Buddhism and Shinto, and known as one of Shichifukujin (Seven Deities of Good Luck).

It is a deity of the Shinto religion that was created by combining Daikouten of Mikkyo and Okuninushi-no mikoto, so called syncretism of Buddhism and Shinto, and known as one of Shichifukujin (Seven Deities of Good Luck).

It is a deity of the Shinto religion that was created by combining Daikokuten of Mikkyo and Okuninushi no mikoto, so called syncretism of Buddhism and Shinto, and known as one of Shichifukujin (Seven Deities of Good Luck).

sen.j: ヒンドゥー教のシヴァ神の化身であるマハーカーラは、インド密教に取り入れられた。
sen.e: Maha kala, a reincarnation of Hindu deity Shiva, was incorporated into the Indian Mikkyo.
Maha kala, a reincarnation of Hindu deity Shiva, was incorporated into the Indian Mikkyo.
Maha kala, an incarnation of the Hindu deity Shiva, was adopted into the Indian Mikkyo religion.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました

sen.j: “マハー”とは大（もしくは偉大なる）、“カーラ”とは時あるいは黒（暗黒）を意味するので大黒天と名づく。
sen.e: It was named Daikokuten (大黒天) because "Maha" means big (大) (or great) and "kala" means time or black (黒) (darkness (暗黒)).
It was named Daikokuten (大黒天) because "Maha" means big (大) (or great) and "kala" means time or black (黒) (darkness (暗黒)).
It was named Daikokuten (大黒天) because "Maha" means big (大) (or great) and "kala" means time or black (黒) (darkness (暗黒)).

sen.j: あるいは大暗黒天とも漢訳される。
sen.e: It is also translated into Chinese character as 大暗黒天 (Daiankokuten).
It is also translated into Chinese characters as 大暗黒天 (Daiankokuten).
It is also translated into Chinese characters as 大暗黒天 (Daiankokuten).

sen.j: その名の通り、青黒い身体に憤怒相をした護法善神である。
sen.e: As its name indicates, it is a Goho zenjin (good deity protecting dharma) with blue-black body and funnuso (feature with fury).
As its name indicates, it is a Goho zenjin (good deity protecting dharma) with a blue-black body and funnuso (feature with fury).
As its name suggests, Daiankokuten is a Goho zenjin (good deity that protects dharma) with a blue-black body and angry countenance.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました

sen.j: 密教の伝来とともに、日本にも伝わった。
sen.e: It was introduced into Japan together with Mikkyo.
It was introduced into Japan together with Mikkyo.
It was introduced into Japan together with Mikkyo.

sen.j: 日本で大黒天といえば一般的には神田明神の大黒天（大国天）像に代表されるように神道の大国主と神仏習合した日本独自の神をさすことが多い。
sen.e: In Japan, the term of Daikokuten normally refers to Japan's own deity that was created by combining it with Okuninushi-no mikoto of Shinto religion, such as the statue of Daikokuten (大国天 : Daikokuten) enshrined at Kanda Myojin.

In Japan, the term of Daikokuten normally refers to Japan's own deity that was created by combining it with Okuninushi-no mikoto of the Shinto religion, such as the statue of Daikokuten (大国天 : Daikokuten) enshrined at Kanda Myojin.

In Japan, the term of Daikokuten normally refers to Japan's own deity that was created by combining it with Okuninushi no mikoto of the Shinto religion, such as the statue of Daikokuten (大国天: Daikokuten) enshrined at Kanda Myojin Shrine.
sen.cmt: ハイフン削除Shrine補足スペース削除

sen.j: ヒンドゥー教
sen.e: Hindu religion
Hindu religion
Hindu religion

sen.j: マハーカーラは、戦闘・財福・冥府という3つの性格を持つ。
sen.e: Maha kala has three natures, namely a deity of battle, a deity of fortune and a deity of the underworld.
Maha kala has three natures, namely a deity of battle, a deity of fortune, and a deity of the underworld.
Maha kala has three aspects; namely, those relating to battle, good fortune, and the underworld.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました

sen.j: 破戒・戦闘を司る神としては、尸林に住み隠形・飛行に通じて、血肉を喰らう神である。
sen.e: As a deity who presides over the violation of precepts and battles, it resides in shirin (cemetery), excels in ongyo (disappearing and concealing) and flying, and devours blood and meat.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外処理
sen.e: As a deity presiding over the violation of precepts and battles, it resides in shirin (cemetery), excels in ongyo (disappearing and concealing) and flying, and devours blood and meat.

As a deity that presides over violations of Buddhist precepts and battles, Maha kala resides in shirin (cemeteries), excels in ongyo (disappearance and concealment) and flying, and devours blood and meat.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました

sen.j: この神を祀れば加護して戦いに勝つという。
sen.e: People believed that they could win a battle by worshipping it.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外処理
sen.e: People believed that they could win a battle by worshipping it.
People believed that they could win a battle by worshipping it.

sen.j: 財福としてはヴィシュヌや地天の化身として、インドの寺院にて祀られる。
sen.e: As a deity of fortune, it is enshrined at Indian Temples as a reincarnation of Vishnu or Jiten.
As a deity of fortune, it is enshrined at Indian Temples as a reincarnation of Vishnu or Jiten.
A deity of fortune, Maha kala is enshrined in Indian Temples as an incarnation of Vishnu or Jiten.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました

sen.j: 冥府としては、焔摩天と同一視して塚に住むという。
sen.e: As a deity of the underworld, he is deemed as the same deity with Emmaten and resides in tsuka (mound).
As a deity of the underworld, he is deemed as the same deity as Emmaten and resides in the tsuka (mound).
As a deity of the underworld, he is deemed as the same deity as Enmaten and resides in the tsuka (mound).

tit.j: インド密教・チベット仏教

sen.j: シヴァ神のマハーカーラがそのまま密教に取り入れたため、初期の大黒天はシヴァと同様に四本の手に三叉戟、棒、輪、索をそれぞれ持った像として描かれた。
sen.e: As Maha kala, namely Shiva, was introduced in Mikkyo as it was, Daikokuten was initially drawn in the same way with Shiva as the image that held a trident, a stick, a ring and a rope in its four hands.

As Maha kala, namely Shiva, was introduced in Mikkyo as it was, Daikokuten was initially drawn in the same way with Shiva as the image that held a trident, a stick, a ring and a rope in its four hands.

Since Mahakala--or in other words, Shiva--was introduced into Mikkyo without modification, Daikokuten was initially depicted in the same manner as Shiva, showing his four hands holding a trident, a staff, a ring, and a rope.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました

sen.j: さらには、ブラフマーとヴィシュヌをも吸収していき、ヒンドゥー教の三神一体（プラフマー・ヴィシュヌ・シヴァ）に対応した三面六臂の憤怒相の大黒天（マハーカーラ）も登場した。
sen.e: Then, with absorbing Burafuma and Vishnu, Daikokuten (Maha kala) statue of Sanmen roppi (Buddhist statue with three faces and six arms) and funnuso, which corresponded to Trimurti of Hindu (Burafuma, Vishnu and Shiva), appeared.

Then, with absorbing Burafuma and Vishnu, Daikokuten (Maha kala) statue of Sanmen roppi (Buddhist statue with three faces and six arms) and funnuso, which corresponded to Trimurti of Hindu (Burafuma, Vishnu and Shiva), appeared.

Later, however, Brahma and Vishnu were absorbed into Daikokuten (Maha kala) to create a figure with three faces, six arms, and an angry countenance that corresponded to the Trimurti of the Hindu religion (Brahma, Vishnu and Shiva).
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました

sen.j: 後期密教を継承したチベット仏教では、大黒天（マハーカーラ）の像容は多彩であり、一面ニ臂・一面四臂・一面六臂・三面ニ臂・三面四臂・三面六臂などがある。
sen.e: In Tibetan Buddhism which succeeded the latter Mikkyo, there are a variety of Daikokuten statues such as Ichimen nihizo (Buddhist statue with one face and two arms), Ichimen shihizo (Buddhist statue with one face and four arms), Ichimen roppizo (Buddhist statue with one face and six arms), Sanmen nihizo (Buddhist statue with three faces and two arms), Sanmen Shihizo (Buddhist statue with three faces and four arms) and Sanmen roppizo.

In Tibetan Buddhism which succeeded the latter Mikkyo, there is a variety of Daikokuten statues such as Ichimen nihizo (Buddhist statue with one face and two arms), Ichimen shihizo (Buddhist statue with one face and four arms), Ichimen roppizo (Buddhist statue with one face and six arms), Sanmen nihizo (Buddhist statue with three faces and two arms), Sanmen Shihizo (Buddhist statue with three faces and four arms) and Sanmen roppizo.

In Tibetan Buddhism which succeeded the latter Mikkyo, there is a variety of Daikokuten statues such as Ichimen nihizo (Buddhist statue with one face and two arms), Ichimen shihizo (Buddhist statue with one face and four arms), Ichimen roppizo (Buddhist statue with one face and six arms), Sanmen nihizo (Buddhist statue with three faces and two arms), Sanmen shihizo (Buddhist statue with three faces and four arms) and Sanmen roppizo.

sen.j: （シヴァに由来しながらも）シヴァとその妻パールヴァティー、もしくはガネーシャを踏みつけてヒンドゥー教を降伏させて仏教を勝利させる護法尊としての姿が主流となった。
sen.e: (although Daikokuten evolved from Shiva) The mainstream figure of Daikokuten Statue became the figure of the guardian of dharma which defeats Hindu religion and brings about the victory of Buddhism by stamping down Shiva and his wife Parvati or Negasha.

(although Daikokuten evolved from Shiva) The mainstream figure of the Daikokuten Statue became the figure of the guardian of dharma which defeats Hindu religion and brings about the victory of Buddhism by stamping down Shiva and his wife Parvati or Negasha.

Daikokuten eventually began to be depicted as the Dharma guardian who defeats Hinduism and ensures the victory of Buddhism by crushing Shiva and his wife Parvati (or Negasha, in some versions) underfoot--despite the ironic fact that Daikokuten originally evolved from Shiva.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました

sen.j: チベット・モンゴル・ネパールでは貿易商から財の神としての信仰を集め、チベットでは福の神としての民間信仰も生まれた。
sen.e: In Tibet, Mongolia and Nepal, Daikokuten was worshipped by traders as a deity of fortune and in Tibet, a folk belief in which Daikokuten is worshipped as a deity of luck developed.
In Tibet, Mongolia and Nepal, Daikokuten was worshipped by traders as a deity of fortune and in Tibet, a folk belief in which Daikokuten is worshipped as a deity of luck developed.
In Tibet, Mongolia and Nepal, Daikokuten was worshipped by traders as a god of wealth and in Tibet, a folk belief in Daikokuten as a god of good luck began to spread.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました

sen.j: 日本には密教の伝来とともに伝わり、天部と言われる仏教の守護神達の一人とされた。
sen.e: Daikokuten was introduced into Japan together with Mikkyo and was believed to be one of the guardian deities of Buddhism called Tenbu.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外処理
sen.e: Daikokuten was introduced into Japan together with Mikkyo and was believed to be one of the guardian deities of Buddhism called Tenbu.
Daikokuten was introduced into Japan together with Mikkyo and was believed to be one of the guardian deities of Buddhism called Tenbu.

sen.j: 軍神・戦闘神、富貴爵禄の神または厨房・食堂の神ともされる。
sen.e: He was also believed to be a deity of army/battle, a deity of fortune or a deity of kitchen/dinning room.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外処理
sen.e: He was also believed to be a deity of the army/battle, a deity of fortune or a deity of the kitchen/dinning room.
He was also considered a deity of battle and war, a deity of good fortune, or a deity of the kitchen and dinning room.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました

sen.j: ただし、日本で福徳相が多いのは、中国においてマハーカーラの3つの性格のうち、財福を強調して祀られたものが、日本に伝えられたことによる。
sen.e: The reason why many of Daikokuten statues in Japan have fukutokuso (feature with happiness and prosperity) is because China-made statues that emphasized, out of three natures of Maha kala, the nature of fortune and happiness were introduced into Japan.

The reason why many Daikokuten statues in Japan have fukutokuso (features of happiness and prosperity) is because China-made statues that emphasized, that from out of the three natures of Maha kala, the nature of fortune and happiness were introduced into Japan.

But the reason many Daikokuten statues in Japan feature fukutokuso (a happy, contented facial expression) is due to the influence of China, where of the three aspects of Mahakala the one most emphasized and worshipped was that of wealth.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました

sen.j: 本来の像容は、一面二臂もしくは三面六臂で、青黒（しょうこく）か黒色で忿怒（いかり）の相で表現される。
sen.e: Daikokuten was originally expressed as the statue of Ichimen nihi or Sanmen roppi with blue-black or black body and funnuso (fury).
Daikokuten was originally expressed as the statue of Ichimen nihi or Sanmen roppi with a blue-black or black body and funnuso (fury).
Daikokuten was originally expressed as the statue of Ichimen nihi or Sanmen roppi with a blue-black or black body and funnuso (fury).

sen.j: 胎蔵界曼荼羅での大黒天は、シヴァとその聖なる白牛ナンディン（白い水牛が中国や日本で認識されずに、山羊や兎の姿で誤描写）を降伏させている憤怒相で描かれている。
sen.e: In Gharba-mandala, Daikokuten is drawn as the one who is defeating Shiva and his sacred white buffalo Nandin (in China or Japan, it was wrongly drawn as a goat or rabbit because a white buffalo was not recognized there) with funnuso.

In Gharba-mandala, Daikokuten is drawn as the one who is defeating Shiva and his sacred white buffalo Nandin (in China or Japan, it was incorrectly drawn as a goat or rabbit because a white buffalo was not recognized there) with funnuso.

In Gharba-mandala, Daikokuten is depicted as defeating Shiva and his sacred white buffalo, Nandin (in China or Japan, Nandin was incorrectly drawn as a goat or rabbit because a white buffalo was not recognized there) with an angry expression on his face.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました

sen.j: なお唐代成立の偽経とされる「大黒天神法」には、烏帽子・袴姿で右手の拳を腰に当てて、左手で大きな袋を左肩に背負う厨房神・財神として描かれている。
sen.e: In "Daikokutenjin ho", which is believed to be a false sutra created in Tang period, Daikokuten is drawn as a deity of kitchen/fortune that put on eboshi (formal headwear for court nobles) and hakama with a right knuckle placed on the waist and a big bag been carried on the left shoulder by a left hand.

In "Daikokutenjin ho", which is believed to be a false sutra created in the Tang period, Daikokuten is drawn as a deity of the kitchen/fortune that put on eboshi (formal headwear for court nobles) and hakama with a right knuckle placed on the waist and a big bag been carried on the left shoulder with his left hand.

In the "Daitokuten jinho," believed to be a fake sutra created in Tang-period China, he is characterized as god of both wealth and the kitchen, and is depicted wearing eboshi (the formal cap for court nobles) and hakama with his right fist at his side and his left hand clutching a large bag he is slinging over his left shoulder.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました

sen.j: また二臂の立像で身の丈は通常は五尺であるが不定である。
sen.e: Although the height of the standing statue of nihi is normally 1.65 m, it is divesified.
Although the height of the standing statue of nihi is normally 1.65 m, it is divesified.
Although the height of a standing statue of nihi is normally 1.65 m, this can vary.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました

sen.j: この姿は鎌倉期の頃までとされる。
sen.e: Statues of such figure were produced until the Kamakura Period.
Statues of such figures were produced until the Kamakura Period.
Statues of such figures were produced until the Kamakura period.

sen.j: 像容はほとんどが一面だが、日本で信仰が広がると毘沙門天・弁才天と合体した三面大黒天も誕生した。
sen.e: Although most of statues have one face, Sanmen Daikokuten (Daikokuten with three faces), which was the combination of Daikokuten,Bishamonten and Benzaiten, was created in conjunction with the spread of Daikokuten belief in Japan.

Although most of the statues have one face, Sanmen Daikokuten (Daikokuten with three faces), which was the combination of Daikokuten,Bishamonten and Benzaiten, was created in conjunction with the spread of the Daikokuten belief in Japan.

Almost all statues have just one face, but as belief in Daitokuten proliferated throughout Japan, Sanmen (three-faced) Daikokuten, which combine Daikokuten, Bishamonten, and Benzaiten into one body, began to appear.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました

sen.j: また、まれに観世音寺（福岡県）にある大黒天立像のように憤怒相の像も見られる。
sen.e: Though uncommon, there also exists statues with funnuso such as the standing statue of Daikokuten enshrined at Kanzeon-ji Temple (Fukuoka Prefecture).
Though uncommon, there also exists statues with funnuso such as the standing statue of Daikokuten enshrined at Kanzeon-ji Temple (Fukuoka Prefecture).
Though uncommon, there also exists statues with funnuso such as the standing statue of Daikokuten enshrined at Kanzeon-ji Temple (Fukuoka Prefecture).

sen.j: 密教を通じて伝来したことから真言宗や天台宗で信仰された。
sen.e: As Daikokuten was introduced together with Mikkyo, it was worshipped in the Shingon Sect and the Tendai Sect.
As Daikokuten was introduced together with Mikkyo, it was worshipped by the Shingon and the Tendai Sects.
As Daikokuten was introduced together with Mikkyo, it was worshipped by the Shingon and the Tendai Sects.

sen.j: 室町時代になると日蓮宗においても盛んに信仰された。
sen.e: In Muromachi Period, it was also eagerly worshipped in the Nichiren Sect.
In the Muromachi Period, it was also eagerly worshipped in the Nichiren Sect.
In the Muromachi period, it was also eagerly worshipped in the Nichiren Sect.

sen.j: ちなみに大黒のシンボルでもある袋の中身は、七宝が入っているといわれている。
sen.e: Incidentally, the contents of the bag symbolizing Daikokuten is said to be seven kinds of treasure.
Incidentally, the contents of the bag symbolizing Daikokuten is said to be seven kinds of treasures.
Incidentally, the contents of the bag symbolizing Daikokuten is said to be seven kinds of treasures.

sen.j: 神道
sen.e: Shinto religion
Shinto religion
Shinto religion

sen.j: 日本においては、大黒の「だいこく」が大国に通じるため、古くから神道の神である大国主と混同され、習合した。
sen.e: In Japan, Daikoukuten was confused from long ago with Okuninushi-no-mikoto (大国主), a deity of Shinto, because "Daikoku" reminded "大国 (daikoku)", and both were combined eventually.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外処理
sen.e: In Japan, Daikoukuten was confused from long ago with Okuninushi-no-mikoto (大国主), a deity of Shinto, because "Daikoku" reminded people of "大国 (daikoku)," and both were eventually combined.

In Japan, because the daikoku (lit. "great black") from Daikokuten sounded the same as the daikoku (lit. "great land") from the ancient Shinto deity Okuninushi no mikoto (which can also be written "Daikoku no shu"), the distinction between the two blurred, and they were eventually combined.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました

sen.j: 当初は破壊と豊穣の神として信仰される。
sen.e: Initially, Daikokuten was worshipped as a deity of destruction and abundant harvest.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外処理
sen.e: Initially, Daikokuten was worshipped as a deity of destruction and abundant harvest.
Initially, Daikokuten was worshipped as a deity of destruction and abundant harvest.

sen.j: 後に豊穣の面が残り、七福神の一柱の大黒様として知らる食物・財福を司る神となった。
sen.e: Later, only the aspect of abundant harvest survived and it became a deity that presides over food and fortune, known as "Daikokusama", one of Shichifukujin.
Later, only the aspect of abundant harvest survived and it became a deity that presides over food and fortune, known as "Daikokusama," one of Shichifukujin.

Later the destructive aspect dropped away to leave only the abundant harvest aspect, which is how Daikokuten, known as "Daikokusama," became the god presiding over food and wealth, and was counted one of the seven Shichifukujin.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました

sen.j: 室町時代以降は「大国主命（おおくにぬしのみこと）」の民族的信仰と習合されて、微笑の相が加えられた。
sen.e: Since the Muromachi Period, Daikokuten was combined with ethnic belief of "Okuninushi-no-mikoto" and the statue with smiling face was created.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外処理
sen.e: Since the Muromachi Period, Daikokuten was combined with ethnic belief of "Okuninushi-no-mikoto" and a statue with a smiling face was created.
Starting in the Muromachi period, belief in Daikokuten began to merge with folk belief in "Okuninushi no mikoto," which is why Daikokuten statues with smiling faces started to appear.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました

sen.j: さらに江戸時代になると米俵に乗るといった現在よく知られる像容となった。
sen.e: Further, the statue mounting on a rice bag, which is popular at present, was created in the Edo Period.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外処理
sen.e: Further, the statue mounted on a rice bag, which is popular at present, was created in the Edo Period.
Beginning in the Edo period, statues of Daikokuten showing him perched atop a bag of rice, perhaps the most well-known type of Daikokuten statue today, began to appear.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました

sen.j: 現在においては一般には米俵に乗り福袋とうちでのこづちを持った微笑の長者形で表される。
sen.e: Currently, Daikokuten is generally expressed as the figure of a wealthy person who is holding fukubukuro (literally lucky bag) and uchidenokozuchi (a magic wand) while mounting on a rice bag.
Currently, Daikokuten is generally expressed as the figure of a wealthy person who is holding fukubukuro (literally lucky bag) and uchidenokozuchi (a magic wand) while mounted on a rice bag.
Nowadays, Daikokuten is usually depicted as a very wealthy man standing on a bag of rice and holding both a fukubukuro (lit. "lucky bag") and an uchidenokuzochi (a magic wand).
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました

sen.j: 袋を背負っているのは、大国主が日本神話で最初に登場する因幡の白兎の説話において、八十神たちの荷物を入れた袋を持っていたためである。
sen.e: The reason why Daikokuten carries a bag on its shoulder is that according to the anecdote of Inaba no Shirousagi, which firstly appears in the Japanese mythology, Okuninushi-no-mikoto carried a bag containing the luggage of yasogami (many deities).

The reason why Daikokuten carries a bag on its shoulder is that according to the anecdote of Inaba no Shirousagi, which firstly appears in the Japanese mythology, Okuninushi-no-mikoto carried a bag containing the luggage of yasogami (many deities).

Daikokuten is shown with a bag slung over his shoulder is because according to the legend of Inaba no Shirousagi--which marks the god's first appearance in Japanese mythology--Okuninushi no mikoto would carry a bag filled with the personal items of the yasogami (lit. "eighty gods", meaning a large group of deities).
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました

sen.j: また、大国主がスサノオの計略によって焼き殺されそうになった時にネズミが助けたという説話（大国主の神話根の国訪問を参照）から、鼠が大黒天の神使であるとされる。
sen.e: Further, a rat is deemed as Daikokuten's deity messenger based on the anecdote that a rat saved Okuninushi's life when he was to be burnt to death by Susanoo's trick (refer to the mythology of Okuninushi-no-mikoto's visit to Nenokuni (land of root)).

Further, the rat is deemed as Daikokuten's deity messenger based on the anecdote that a rat saved Okuninushi's life when he was about to be burnt to death being tricked by Susanoo (refer to the mythology of Okuninushi-no-mikoto's visit to Nenokuni - land of root).

Along the same vein, the rat became Daikokuten's divine messenger because of a myth that a rat saved Okuninushi from being burnt to death after the god was tricked by Susanoo (for more information, see the myth of Okuninushi no mikoto's visit to Nenokuni, lit. "root land").
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました

sen.j: 伊豆山神社（伊豆山権現）では、夫が大国主大神で妻が神須勢理毘売命（すせりひめのみこと）である夫婦大黒天像がある。
sen.e: The statues of Daikokuten and Suserihime-no mikoto, his wife, are enshrined at Izusan-jinja Shrine (Izusan Gongen) as a couple.
The statues of Daikokuten and Suserihime-no mikoto, his wife, are enshrined at Izusan-jinja Shrine (Izusan Gongen) as a couple.
Statues of both Daikokuten and Suserihime no mikoto, his wife, are enshrined as a married couple at Izusan-jinja Shrine.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました

sen.j: 大黒とえびすは各々七福神の一柱であるが、寿老人と福禄寿が二柱で一組で信仰される事と同様に、一組で信仰されることが多い。
sen.e: Although each of Daikoku and Ebisu is an independent deity of Shichifukujin, they are usually worshipped as a pair in the same way as the pair of Jurojin (deity of longevity) and Fukurokuju (tall headed deity of happiness, wealth and long life).

Although both Daikoku and Ebisu are independent deities of Shichifukujin, they are usually worshipped as a pair in the same way as the pair of Jurojin (deity of longevity) and Fukurokuju (tall headed deity of happiness, wealth and long life).

Although both Daikoku and Ebisu are independent deities of Shichifukujin, they are usually worshipped as a pair in the same way as the pair of Jurojin (deity of longevity) and Fukurokuju (tall headed deity of happiness, wealth and long life).

sen.j: 神楽などでも恵比寿舞と大黒舞が夙（つと）に知られている。
sen.e: From long ago, Ebisumai (Ebisu dancing) and Daikokumai (Daikoku dancing) have been widely Known among various kinds of Kagura (sacred music and dancing performed at shrines).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外処理
sen.e: From long ago, Ebisumai (Ebisu dancing) and Daikokumai (Daikoku dancing) have been widely Known among various kinds of Kagura (sacred music and dancing performed at shrines).
From long ago, Ebisumai (Ebisu dancing) and Daikokumai (Daikoku dancing) have been widely known among various kinds of Kagura (sacred music and dancing performed at shrines).

sen.j: このことは大黒が五穀豊穣の農業の神である面と恵比寿が大漁追福の漁業の神である面に起因すると考えられている。
sen.e: The background of the above is believed to be the fact that Daikoku is a deity of agriculture that brings about a good harvest and Ebisu is a deity of fishery that brings about a big catch.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外処理
sen.e: The background of the above is believed to be the fact that Daikoku is a deity of agriculture that brings about a good harvest and Ebisu is a deity of fishery that brings about a big catch.
This is believed to be due to the fact that Daikoku is the deity of agriculture that brings about a good harvest and Ebisu is the deity of fishery that brings about a plentiful catch.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました

sen.j: また商業においても農産物や水産物は主力であったことから商売の神としても信仰されるようになっていった。
sen.e: Daikokuten has also been worshipped as a deity of commerce because the products of agriculture and fishery used to be the main commodities for trading.
Daikokuten has also been worshipped as a deity of commerce because the products of agriculture and fishery used to be the main commodities for trading.
Daikokuten has also been worshipped as a deity of commerce because the products of agriculture and fishery used to be the main commodities for trading.

sen.j: 民間の神道においてや子作り信仰と呼ばれるものがあり、大黒天の像が、米俵に載っている（写真参照）のは実は男性器をあらわしている言われる。
sen.e: In a folk Shinto religion, there exists a belief called kodakara (children) belief or kozukuri (having a baby) belief and according to such belief, the statue of Daikokuten mounting on a rice bag (refer to the photograph) is believed to be the one indicating the male sex organ.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外処理
sen.e: In a Shinto folk religion, there exists a belief called kodakara (children) or kozukuri (having a baby) and according to such beliefs, the statue of Daikokuten mounted on a rice bag (refer to the photograph) is believed to be the one indicating the male sex organ.

In Shinto folk religion, various beliefs exist about kodakara (children) and kozukuri (making babies); under such beliefs, statues of Daikokuten atop a bag of rice (see photograph) are thought to represent the male sex organ.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました

sen.j: 具体的には帽子は男性器の先端部分をあらわし、体が男性器本体、そして米俵が陰嚢であるとの俗説がある。
sen.e: To put it concretely, it is believed that a hat, a body and a rice box indicates the tip of male sex organ, male sex organ itself and the scrotum respectively.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外処理
sen.e: More specifically, it is believed that a hat, a body, and a rice box indicates the tip of the male sex organ, and the scrotum respectively.
More specifically, folk belief holds that his hat, body, and rice bag represent the tip of the penis, the penis itself, and the scrotum, respectively.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました
